events.target_title: Unable to get gparted to run on tablet
Unable to get gparted to run on tablet

note.body:
I am sorry my report was not of your liking. I am an amateur and I don't
understand your program.
I used your current tools to make a bootable USB pen drive of gparted as
per your website. My tablet a viglen connect 8, crashed a few weeks ago and
will no longer boot to windows 10.  The tablet will boot to the uefi shell,
or the boot menu or the uefi setup. If you attach a USB hub, keyboard and a
bootable pendrive you can make the tablet try and boot from USB. (It only
has one micro USB port). With a suitable fat32/gpt formatted USB drive and
a windows 10 iso ( using Rufus to make such a drive) the tablet will on the
third attempt try to boot the drive. The first attempt it will stop at the
setup prompt or the OEM logo depending on the setting of the fast boot. The
second attempt it will boot to the uefi shell. The third attempt it will
try the usb. This is the boot order in the default setup boot override
order. It does not seem to matter what is in the user setup order.
Using a uefi memory test utility (mem86) I have used a bootable USB to
check that the ram (1GB) is fine.
Using the gparted bootable USB the tablet boots to a screen with annoying
disk pictures obscuring text. I blanked out the picture using a photo
editing software on another computer to find text at the top offering
options for gparted with the lowest option highlighted in red and the
bottom of the screen giving help for the commands. Choosing any thing other
than the "other options" goes to a blank screen. Any choice from the other
option also leads to a blank screen. The only option that works is entering
a "c" when I get a "grub" prompt! The tablet does not turn off or reboot on
exiting and only a long press (15 seconds) of the power button will turn it
off. The uefi shell only appears in the absence of a bootable USB drive.
The tablet has a single partitioned emmc drive of 32GB. The first partition
(fs0) holds a windows 10 recovery image. The second partition is a boot
partition I think(fs1). The third is the area used for the now not working
windows 10 implementation. All three partitions are write protected when
within the uefi shell. Any USB becomes the fourth (fs3) which is not write
protected! The uefi shell also shows block aliases?
The grub help scrolls off the top of the tablet! and is not very specific,
the text is tiny needing a magnifying lens to read some of it.

Please feel free to ask specific questions
Ken

events.target_title: Gnome Boxes  3.34.1-1.fc31.1  on Fedora 31 can't run Windows 10 image
building fails with "syntax error near unexpected token..."

note.body:
On Ubuntu 16.04, installing `libgirepository1.0-dev` and rerunning `./autogen.sh` fixed the issue for me (although the build failed after that, because the GTK+ version is too low).

I think this is because `gobject-introspection` does not include the `.pc` file required by `pkg-config`. `libgirepository1.0-dev` includes `/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/pkgconfig/gobject-introspection-1.0.pc`.

events.target_title: Fix #22, solve on [=] key if the input is not a variable name.
Calculate the result when the = key is pressed

note.body:
Today I realized I wanted this feature, came here to file an issue but found this very old one, so I’ve linked my pull request to it instead.

When pressing [=], it checks whether the expression entered so far is not just a variable name, in which case it pretends that the user pressed Enter instead. Otherwise it will insert “=” to allow assignment.

My first implementation had a duplication of the code for evaluating the expression, but I thought that modifying `keyval` to simulate Enter is more robust w.r.t. changes in the calls to `function_completion_window_visible()` and `expression.solve()`.

events.target_title: Provide GtkEmojiChooser as public API in 3.x

note.body:
In fact we can (GtkSourceView will be a better thing), but actually the chatview is a generated HTML page with a text input and rendered by webkitgtk. Sure, we can remove that part and redo this whole part on all platforms that use the same generated page, but there is no really need to do that for now (and this will a GtkSourceView). GtkPopovers, theme support or other Gtk stuff is easily plugguable for now. So it's not a priority at all and this also avoid to do the stuff on multiple platforms.

But the thing is:

+ Actually, a lot of projects are duplicating the code of the GtkEmojiChooser and I think it's dirty.
+ This also brings more bugs to take care at multiple places. For example, I see that on any webpage rendered by WebkitGtk, since I can insert an emoji in an input (because they bundle their own EmojiChooser), you can also open the GtkEmojiChooser on a GtkWebkitEmojiChooser (because it's a GtkEntry in their bundled widget). 
+ The user must use a GtkEntry to show that popup even if they want that popup on another place (cf the comment of Christopher)
+ Or they can create their own EmojiChooser, but imho it's just inconsistent with the rest of the UI and duplicate code.

events.target_title: MappingNotify event freezes drawing windows in Gnome for ~100ms

note.body:
I'm trying out some stuff on Ubuntu 19.10 right now actually.
If you wanna help me or guide me I'd be more than happy to receive your help.
Send me an email `REMOVED` .

EDIT:
I think I've got this working actually. So I thought it'd be writing down in case someone else comes around wanting to duplicate it (perhaps those over at the [Ubuntu Bug Report Forums](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/meta-gnome3/+bug/1777708)). Be aware though, I **JUST** have it working now and have no idea if something will break later down the line. I bricked my Ubuntu installation **twice** trying to get it to work.

So I'm running **Ubuntu 19.10** now, for this to work any older version will not work (at least not with this method).
So currently 19.10 is running gnome-shell 3.34.1 and we'll need to downgrade to 3.34.0 as this includes the fix, before it was reverted. Unfortunately the compiled packages have been removed so we'll have to download and install them manually and figure out the dependencies so things don't break.

Luckily however, Launchpad has some built packages, so we'll need to download for mutter:
* [gir1.2-mutter-5_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mutter/3.34.0-3ubuntu1/+build/17795309/+files/gir1.2-mutter-5_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb)
* [libmutter-5-0_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mutter/3.34.0-3ubuntu1/+build/17795309/+files/libmutter-5-0_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb)
* [mutter-common_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_all.deb](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mutter/3.34.0-3ubuntu1/+build/17795309/+files/mutter-common_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_all.deb)
* [mutter_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mutter/3.34.0-3ubuntu1/+build/17795309/+files/mutter_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb)

and for gnome-shell:
* [gnome-shell-common_3.34.0-1ubuntu1_all.deb](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-shell/3.34.0-1ubuntu1/+build/17748788/+files/gnome-shell-common_3.34.0-1ubuntu1_all.deb)
* [gnome-shell_3.34.0-1ubuntu1_amd64.deb](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-shell/3.34.0-1ubuntu1/+build/17748788/+files/gnome-shell_3.34.0-1ubuntu1_amd64.deb)

If the direct links doesn't work, here's where I found all the dpkg files, or if you're not running amd64 architecture, you should also be able to find alternatives:
* [mutter-3.34.0-3ubuntu1](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mutter/3.34.0-3ubuntu1/+build/17795309)
* [gnome-shell-3.34.0-1ubuntu1](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-shell/3.34.0-1ubuntu1/+build/17748788)

So, once you've got all the files you need. Open the terminal and the following command to exit the desktop enviroment (I don't know if this is needed but why not?):
```
sudo init 3
```

Then install each and everyone of your dpkg files with `sudo dpkg -i /path/to/deb/file` like so:
```
sudo dpkg -i gir1.2-mutter-5_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb
sudo dpkg -i libmutter-5-0_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb
sudo dpkg -i mutter-common_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_all.deb
sudo dpkg -i mutter_3.34.0-3ubuntu1_amd64.deb
sudo dpkg -i gnome-shell-common_3.34.0-1ubuntu1_all.deb
sudo dpkg -i gnome-shell_3.34.0-1ubuntu1_amd64.deb
```
Do not worry if it complains or warns about missing dependencies or breaking dependencies. This is because you have a newer version installed, and we're replacing them one by one.

Once finished, we start the desktop environment again with:
```
sudo init 5
```

Finally, we wanna let **APT** know not to update these packages, because that would undo everything. We do that by running following:
```
sudo apt-mark hold gir1.2-mutter-5
sudo apt-mark hold libmutter-5-0
sudo apt-mark hold mutter-common
sudo apt-mark hold mutter
sudo apt-mark hold gnome-shell-common
sudo apt-mark hold gnome-shell
```

Now you're done!
Once everything has been fixed and maybe you do want to upgrade all your versions, just run the previous commands but substitute **hold** with **unhold**. That should tell **APT** that it's okay to upgrade those packages again.

events.target_title: Update idl-exelis.lang
Update idl-exelis.lang

note.body:
Thanks for quick reply.

The ```idl.lang``` is unrelated - it handles the "Interface Description Language": https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interface_description_language

The ```idl-exelis.lang``` handles "Interactive Data Language": https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IDL_(programming_language)

The mention of *Exelis* is quite misleading. IDL is a proprietary tool that was started back in 1970-ties, first owned by *Research Systems Inc. (RSI)*, then in 2006 it was offered by *ITT Visual Information Solutions*, then since 2011 as *Exelis Visual Information Solutions*, and since 2015 by *Harris Geospatial Solutions*. In addition, a fork of IDL with the same basic syntax exists and is called PV-WAVE (first offered by *Precision Visuals*, then by *Visual Numerics* and now by *Rogue Wave Software*). Thus, I doubt "Exelis" helps anyone now to disambiguate one IDL from another IDL...

On the other hand, the GNU Data Language - open clone of IDL exists for good 15 years now - it is related to IDL in a similar manner as Octave to Matlab, etc.

Vim uses the "idlang" identifier: https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/master/runtime/syntax/idlang.vim

ohcount uses "idl_pvwave" with "": https://github.com/blackducksoftware/ohcount/blob/master/src/parsers/idl_pvwave.rl

events.target_title: Crash on any attempt to save a File in 2.10.14 on Windows 8.1
Crash on any attempt to save a File in 2.10.14 on Windows 8.1

note.body:
I had started Gimp in debug mode and played around with compatibility-modes and elevated Administrator mode. In all cases, Gimp starts with hundreds of same assertion exceptions «GLib-GIO-CRITICAL **: 22:12:56.646: g_content_type_is_a: assertion 'supertype != NULL' failed». No error message is created in the debug window, when the ntdll.dll exception is thrown. Further, I noticed, when I start the program as a user, a click on the File-Menue creates this exeption. When I start the program with the context-menue option "Run as Administrator", no crash occurs. Therefore, I suspect, there is an attempt to write somthing to a location, without suitable rights. Additionally, this error is not caught. The same thing happens on two, fully patched Windows 8.1x32 machines. My workaround is to start Gimp with the Windows command «C:\Windows\System32\runas.exe /noprofile /env /savecred /user:%USERDOMAIN%\Administrator "C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\bin\gimp-2.10.exe"». I know, it isn't the pristine best practice of a Sysadmin - but it works.

[gimp2.10.14debug01.txt](/uploads/fe12240ae04c6d6a9802ff8194fa177e/gimp2.10.14debug01.txt)

![Gimp2.10.14debug01](/uploads/cdc9fed2a1b7ff178bff9df41d042665/Gimp2.10.14debug01.PNG)

note.body:
The suggestion to look at the keyboard with xev led me to identifying the likely issue (see https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/552680/why-does-hypertab-not-work-tested-in-ubuntu-gnome-and-xfce). In particular,
```
xmodmap -pm
```
showed that mod5 was overcrowded, where my modifications had been included with the default map (for the xkb US keyboard layout) of:
```
mod4        Super_L (0x25),  Super_R (0x86),  Super_L (0xce),  Hyper_L (0xcf)
mod5        ISO_Level3_Shift (0x5c),  Mode_switch (0xcb)
```
to give
```
mod4        Super_L (0x25),  Super_R (0x86),  Super_L (0xce),  Hyper_L (0xcf)
mod5        <OTHER_KEYS, inc. Hyper_R> ISO_Level3_Shift (0x5c),  Mode_switch (0xcb) 
```
So ISO_Level3_Shift was triggered along Hyper, and thus didn't work.

However, by setting <HYPR> to Super, and then using different mod numbers, Hyper works as advertised. For details, see writeup here: https://github.com/bjohas/Ubuntu-keyboard-map-like-OS-X/blob/master/Hyper%20key.md

events.target_title: PNM export of very big images is extremally slow

note.body:
@lillolollo I managed to fix GEGL and run 2.10.14.

The PNM Export dialog does show now faster, 7 minutes instead of 25 minutes. Still slow and annoying (PNG shows export dialog in seconds, and can save in about 1 minute depending on compression level used). So the issue is not fixed yet (would be interesting to know what changed that it become faster tho, could be compiler optimizations differences tho too, like LTO vs non-LTO stuff). Before Export dialog show up, the CPU is initially fully loaded (2100%) on many cores, but then it oscillates wildly from 50% to 400%.

The saving itself is the same and looks still to be 1 minute and confirmed to be bottlnecked by sshfs mostly.

Also I did notice that during saving both virtual memory usage and residential memory usage in `file-pnm` is steadily growing, so I suspect that during writing some buffers are not freeded in `file-pnm`, possible due to the authors assuming that the `file-pnm` process is short lived and all buffers will be freeded on exit. But the peak residential memory usage was about 10GiB in my case, which is not nice.

This time I managed to record the trace using GIMP Dashboard thingy:

[gimp-performance1.log](/uploads/b9ff8065cb63e6e939e0feaf3011b984/gimp-performance1.log)

events.target_title: PNM export of very big images is extremally slow

note.body: Additional point of information: Merging all layers and making it the size of the image and only exporting when the project has one layer, makes PNM export way faster. The export dialog show after about 55 second. Still slower than PNG (it takes just few seconds there), and the CPU usage is very high during this 55 seconds (500-2400%). And the GIMP process consumes additional 10-11GB of memory.

events.target_title: "Generate optimum palette" makes saturation in lack of white (Convert to index mode)

note.body: Indeed. I did reproduce this. The optimal palette doesn't looks to be ... optimal. I don't know the details, but maybe a datastructure containing most common colours should be computed during calculations? For sufficiently small images this can be done just by simply sorting al pixels by their value, and then counting or finding longest runs. For bigger images, a solution based on Count-Min sketch or more elaborate method (there are few known in literature) would work very well in O(N), where N is total number of pixels, and sub O(N) space, around O(log^2 N) I think (depends on exact parametrization and accuracy required, which doesn't need to be very high for computing optimal palette).

events.target_title: Unable to open folders in Mac Catalina: "Operation not permitted"

note.body:
Hi @samm-git, 

I have the same problems with a Mac bundle for [pspp](https://www.gnu.org/software/pspp/). events.target_title: SayAll: when reading a sentence, start offset of sentence within paragraph is shifted

note.body:
OK, found the strip() that causes all this! It's the one in speech_generator.py's _generateSubstring.

When calling _generateCurrentLineText if the offsets are already known they are not re-computed and a mere substring is done. So within a single paragraph, first call is correct but subsequent calls in the same paragraph will receive a stripped version of the chunk.

Not sure why a substring method would strip its result? There is probably a good reason, but as-is it seems quite strange and error-prone. Any advise @joanmarie? I just commented it out for now and it fixes the issue.

events.target_title: Don't mark word not visible on screen with SSML

note.body:
At the time of marking the text, we don't have an easy way to distinguish between displayed text and "generated" text.

I have a WIP changeset that adds a field in SayAllContext to let scripts tell if the text it contains comes from displayed text or not. I don't see a way to determine this in a unified way since for example libreoffice gives currently everything mixed in a single SayAllContext. 

My test is implemented for Firefox (web script) currently.

What's your opinion on this? See attached file for an overview, but it's based after applying all positioning patches, won't apply on master.

[0001-Tell-that-a-SayAllContext-is-not-displayed-and-don-t.patch](/uploads/3024d151e0dc4440e9613cfa9f9f986e/0001-Tell-that-a-SayAllContext-is-not-displayed-and-don-t.patch)

events.target_title: Don't mark word not visible on screen with SSML

note.body:
At first I suggested that (sorry, internally on Hypra issue), but then we decided that it was better to actually not mark at all. And indeed as you noticed, this patch provides both approaches and one of them is enough.

It really depends on how in the future marking/progress/etc. is intended to be used, if marks may be used for other purposes (and thus, kept) or never needed (and then we may remove them so that it's ready for final reimplementation of progress notifications).

If we decide to leave as you said, the issue is specific to Hypra patches for now then.
